node.title: Access to material properties within computeProperties()
node.bodyText:
Hi all,
Can the material properties of other elements be accessed/modified when the computeProperties() method is being called for one element?
Regards,
Albert

Hello
Not natively. It can be done with some hacking (reinit on neighbor element, compute, reinit on local)
You can access the neighbor material properties in interface_kernels though. If you are using those and the work performed in the material computeProperties() can be moved there, that is an option.
Could you please give us more details about your use case?
Second caveat:
It can be done in the functor material system which we are adding here, and which does not leverage computeProperties but does on-demand computation of matprops : #18395
Guillaume

Hi @GiudGiud,
I am trying to code in a nonlocal return mapping algorithm ( #19003 ). In the algorithm, the plastic multiplier is calculated for all the integration points of the domain simultaneously. I am currently calculating the plastic multiplier in separate std::vector. The vector is updated for each time the  computeQpProperties() is called and after the final call for the last _qp in the domain, my std::vector has the correct values of the plastic multiplier and plastic strain for all of the quadrature poinst, which I want to assign to the _plastic_strain[_qp]  for each element.

@albiedahal you might want to look into compue = false  materials, the getMaterial (not getMaterial_Property_!) call, and the computePropertiesAtQp call. This allows you to trigger material property re-computes on your own terms (e.g. multiple times within a local return mapping solve).

so there is a global quantity that needs to be accessible when you compute the plastic_strain material property.
Can you lag it? Use the one from the previous iteration or even time step?
If so, retrieve an old material property using getMaterialPropertyOld
If not, I would create a UserObject to compute this quantity before computing material properties, then retrieve it when computing material properties.
Using a material property for this quantity does not work (unless you can use an old value) because all material properties are computed roughly (there is dependency resolution etc) at the same time
Instead of the UO, I think @dschwen s solution is preferable btw
You are probably already aware of this, another issue here is that you are going to get a dense matrix using this approach, which may very likely bring you more trouble than it is worth.

node.title: Anomalous console prints during the solve on older HPC
node.bodyText:
Hi,
I noticed after a recent recompile (fresh MOOSE/libMesh/Petsc stack) on an older HPC system that I have console prints telling me the following:
Adapting Mesh
Adapting Mesh.....                                                                   7.03 s
Still Adapting Mesh................................................
Still Adapting Mesh..                                                                        60.40 s
or
Finished Computing Residual                                                         6.99 s
Computing Residual
Updating Displaced Mesh.....                                                       6.81 s
Finished Computing Residual                                                          7.00 s
for what it appears to be every linear iteration.
The problem is a bit large, with some aggressive AMR active (giving something like 5000 dof/proc when max h_level is reached). We are not using displaced mesh also so losing 6.81 seconds for every linear iteration is a bit much for me.
Has anyone seen this before?

Hello
Can you share your input file? We'd have to look to find what is using the displaced mesh.
Guillaume

We are only using the tensor_mechanics Action that sets up the stress-divergence Kernels and the GlobalStrain system to ensure strain periodicity.
I should note that I have noticed the "update displaced mesh issue" for quite some time. I had a thread on the old google group about this.
I have a much simpler input file than the problem above that does not use AMR nor print "Computing Residual" but does print "updating displaced mesh" when the dof/proc gets large enough. Maybe that is the best place to start. Can I send that off-list to you? thanks I will also have to give you access to Ferret.
You can send me that file, either on the email listed on github or on my INL email (swap out gmail for inl.gov)

I know that the tensor_mechanics action can definitely turn on the displaced mesh... it uses it any time you have a large strain formulation (and possibly in other scenarios too).
Is the updating of the displaced mesh the main issue here?  Or are you wanting to turrn off the printing?  You can turn off the printing by using perf_graph_live = false in your Outputs block... or you can turn the time up that it waits before printing by setting perf_graph_live_time_limit = # where # is however many seconds you want it to wait before printing anything.
This is a new system for printing progress that we're still refining.  Feel free to provide feedback on it.

@GiudGiud I granted your github acct Ferret access and sent the input file to your gmail. Thanks!
EDIT @friedmud indeed I put perf_graph_live = false in the outputs block and I am no longer seeing the update displaced mesh (along with computing residual, jacobian etc) prints. However, the problem is damn slow now -  and I worry there is some needless checks related to Update displaced mesh that is causing this.
Yeah - if your issue is that PerfGraphLive exposed something happening that shouldn't be... then that's a different issue.
The TM Action is not turning displaced mesh on, but as soon as you put displacements into [GlobalParams] it is also picked up by the [Mesh] block and will trigger the creation of the displaced mesh.
I've seen similar behavior when I loaded an MPI different from the one used for compilation.

I do get the warning
MPI startup(): Warning: I_MPI_PMI_LIBRARY will be ignored since the hydra process manager was found
at the start up, but I am relatively certain we are using the same MPI during compilation (no change to the loaded modules, etc)

Solution is to set use_displaced_mesh in the [Mesh] block to false when providing displacements.
We ll document that, raised an issue #19049
Thanks @GiudGiud and @dschwen

node.title: Where is the ~/projects directory located?
node.bodyText:
I am following the online installation guide.
I am having difficulty with the last step:  ./run_tests -j 4
The error message: ModuleNotFoundError: No module named 'TestHarness'
This might be due to my confusion where MOOSE_DIR and FRAMEWORK_DIR are located.
For me, the installation guide is clear how to install in conda, but not its relationship to the projects dir
OS: Ubuntu 20.04
Conda MOOSE Environment
https://mooseframework.inl.gov/getting_started/installation/conda.html
This is OK so far:
conda create --name moose -q -y
conda activate moose
conda install moose-tools
conda install moose-libmesh
Obtaining and Building MOOSE
https://mooseframework.inl.gov/getting_started/installation/install_moose.html
This is OK so far:
mkdir ~/projects    Where are you meant to make the /projects folder?
cd ~/projects
git clone https://github.com/idaholab/moose.git
cd moose
git checkout master
cd ~/projects/moose/test
make -j 4
But not this:
./run_tests -j 4
First question:
At this point, I need clarity here regarding my moose and project folders
Is the projects dir in my moose conda env?
Or is it located somewhere else, even another HDD?
Is this path to projects correct?
~/conda_envs/envs/moose/projects
and is this the  path to framework?
~/conda_envs/envs/moose/projects/moose/framework
Therefore:
MOOSE_DIR = ~/conda_envs/envs/moose/
and
FRAMEWORK_DIR = ~/conda_envs/envs/moose/projects/moose/framework
+++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++
Second question:
In Troubleshooting, you use /tmp folder
Where is /tmp in relation to ~/conda_env/env/moose ?
https://mooseframework.inl.gov/help/troubleshooting.html#buildissues
Try building a simple hello world example (there is more text than what is visible, be sure to copy it all):
cd /tmp
cat << EOF > hello.C
Thanks for any help or suggestions

From this post:
#18902
https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/55847507/134444152-d84a78d1-ff4d-412f-97b2-64c3cd4ab784.png
I see that the MOOSE_DIR is in the conda_env,
and FRAMEWORK_DIR is elsewhere, in this case the USER dir on mac OSX
on Ubuntu OS:
MOOSE_DIR = ~/conda_envs/envs/moose/
and
FRAMEWORK_DIR = /media/USER/projects/moose/framework
alternatively,
FRAMEWORK_DIR = /media/USER/some other HDD/projects/moose/framework
Is that now correct?
MOOSE_DIR should be the path to where you cloned moose into. It has nothing to do with conda. If you ran make within the tests directory, MOOSE_DIR should be one level up from this.

@loganharbour
Thanks for replying and clarifying the paths.
I am reinstalling and trying again.
Which page on Moose (mooseframework.inl.gov) has the link to this url:  "Obtaining and Building MOOSE"
https://mooseframework.inl.gov/getting_started/installation/install_moose.html
Installation page has links to install the MOOSE Framework on Linux and macOSX,
https://mooseframework.inl.gov/getting_started/installation/
which lands you on the Install conda moose environment.
https://mooseframework.inl.gov/getting_started/installation/conda.html
This page advises the user to install, compile and test MOOSE by running the following commands in a terminal.
mkdir ~/projects
cd ~/projects
git clone https://github.com/idaholab/moose.git
cd moose
git checkout master
cd ~/projects/moose/test
make -j 4
./run_tests -j 4
That ends in failure with errors.
In fact there is another web page called "Obtaining and Building MOOSE", which is absent from the Installation or Conda pages
https://mooseframework.inl.gov/getting_started/installation/install_moose.html
I stumbled upon on it while googling searches about /projects and setting up the moose framework
The commands on that page are:
"To install MOOSE run the following commands in a terminal."
mkdir ~/projects
cd ~/projects
git clone https://github.com/idaholab/moose.git
cd moose
git checkout master
cd ~/projects/moose
unset PETSC_DIR PETSC_ARCH
./scripts/update_and_rebuild_petsc.sh
./scripts/update_and_rebuild_libmesh.sh
cd ~/projects/moose/test
make -j 4
./run_tests -j 4
Which are considerably different commands to those provided on the conda moose environment page.
I will try this, using:
MOOSE_DIR = the path to where you cloned moose into. MOOSE_DIR is one level up from the test directory.
FRAMEWORK_DIR = MOOSE_DIR/framework

Ok, that worked well!
Set MOOSE_DIR and FRAMEWORK_DIR in both .bashrc and the Makefile in /projects/moose/test
Given the time it takes to get to finally ./run_tests, I wasn't taking any risks.
.....
./run_tests -j 4
Ran 2912 tests in 832.8 seconds. Average test time 0.9 seconds, maximum test time 48.9 seconds.
2912 passed, 96 skipped, 0 pending, 0 failed
All up, the cloning, installing, compiling, testing of moose on "/media/hDD/projects/moose" swallowed 11.4 Gb,
and took a few hours to complete.
Thanks to @loganharbour, problem solved.

node.title: Error: No valid AXIS lines found by GriddedData
node.bodyText:
I'm trying to compile one of the examples for PiecewiseMultilinear function. I copied .i and .txt files to my directory. However, when I try to compile the file, I'm getting the error 'No valid AXIS lines found by GriddedData'. Could you help me to resolve this issue?
Files:
https://github.com/idaholab/moose/blob/next/test/tests/functions/piecewise_multilinear/twoDa.i
https://github.com/idaholab/moose/blob/next/test/tests/functions/piecewise_multilinear/twoD_const.txt

I'm not sure what you've done exactly.  The MOOSE input file twoDa.i does not use the data file twoD_const.txt.  Instead, it uses twoD1.txt, because of the block
  [./bilinear1_fcn]
    type = PiecewiseMultilinear
    data_file = twoD1.txt
  [../]

So, i suspect that you've copied the files, but then modified stuff.  Check your modifications.
andy

I downloaded files again to my directory and run them w/o modifications. However, I'm still getting the same error. All the files I copy from /moose I store on my computer and compile them with ./giraffe-opt -i /mnt/c/Users/Tatiana/Desktop/MOOSE/test/twoD.i
Did you also copy twoD1.txt, since that is the file that is used by twoDa.i.
Yes, if there is no twoD1.txt file the error is 'Error opening file '/mnt/c/Users/Tatiana/Desktop/MOOSE/test/twoD1.txt' from GriddedData.'

This really should not be failing. This is a tested input. i just checked with a fresh MOOSE and it runs fine.
Did you change anything wrt to these systems in Giraffe?
No, I didn't do anything. Will try to update moose
This was added in 2018, I doubt this was ever broken since then. But always a good idea

node.title: Compressible Navier Stokes CGFE Resources
node.bodyText:
For the Compressible Navier Stokes CGFE, are there any resources or test input files for it? I found bump.i in the tests section.
Are there any input files using the Compressible Navier Stokes CGFE method without using the  Modules/Compressible Navier-Stokes System.

Hello
There isnt much resource for this apart from the bump test and the step test. You can ask for access to Pronghorn to get more input files using CNS, here: https://ncrcaims.inl.gov/Identity/Account/Login
You can however look at src/actions/CNSAction.C to see what is done by the Modules/CompressibleNavierStokes syntax precisely.
Our main focus is finite volume for compressible flows, these two PRs enable it:
#18395
#18806
Guillaume
Thank you for the information. May I ask why the focus is on finite volume for compressible flow?
Works a lot better. Conservation of quantities is natural, no need for stabilization, no awkwardness at corners for boundary conditions.

node.title: Function & expression in ParsedMaterial
node.bodyText:
Hello, I'm trying to use both function and expression(if-else) in "function in ParsedMaterial" like below
However, it doesn't work..
(*** ERROR ***
Invalid function
if(aux_eta_tpb > funcOverpotential, 0, 5318)
aux_eta_tpb
in ParsedMaterialHelper.
)
How can I use "funcOverpotential function" in ParsedMaterial?
Thanks.
[Functions]
  [./funcPotentialLSM]
    type = ParsedFunction
    value = 'init_val := if(t = 0, 0.03607, 0);
             init_val +BC_YSZ +E_rev - eta * t'
    vars  = '          BC_YSZ  E_rev   eta'
    vals  = 'numerical_phi_YSZ 1.03665 0.4' # 0.03607+1.03665
  [../]

  [./funcOverpotential]
    type = ParsedFunction
    value = 'eta * t'
    vars  = 'eta'
    vals  = '0.4'
  [../]

  [./funcTimeStepper]
    type = PiecewiseLinear
    x = '0.0  0.1 0.5 1.0' # time_t
    y = '0.01 0.1 0.1 0.2' # time_dt
  [../]
[]

[Materials]
  [./tpbActivity]
    type  = ParsedMaterial
    block = 'PT_TPB_TET4'
    f_name = 'tpbActivity_S0'
    function = 'if(aux_eta_tpb > funcOverpotential, 0, 5318)'
    args = 'aux_eta_tpb'
    # Make values see at output(*.e) file
    outputs = exodus
  [../]
[]

Hello
ParsedMaterial cannot use a function directly (funcOverpotential).
You have to use a GenericFunctionMaterial to transfer the function to a material property. Then make sure to have it listed in material_property_names
Guillaume

node.title: CondaVerificationError
node.bodyText:
Hi Moose expert or user,
When using 'conda update --all' to update my conda environment, as the download of moose-libmesh does not keep going and it is stuck there, I have to force it to break. But when running that command again, I got the CondaVerificationError.  The error message is here.
CondaVerificationError.txt
Could anyone help me with solving this issue? Thank you.

Hello
You might have broken conda a bit by forcing it to break like this.
Can you try cleaning the conda cache? conda clean --all
if that does not do it, you can try conda remove moose-libmesh, and if that fails too then you ll have to go in the conda pkg directory and clean manually.
Also if you feel conda is too slow, please try out the suggestions in this thread (mamba)
#18378
Guillaume

Hello
You might have broken conda a bit by forcing it to break like this. Can you try cleaning the conda cache? conda clean --all if that does not do it, you can try conda remove moose-libmesh, and if that fails too then you ll have to go in the conda pkg directory and clean manually.
Also if you feel conda is too slow, please try out the suggestions in this thread (mamba) #18378
Guillaume

Thank you very much. I fix issue by re-installing conda.

node.title: Polynomial order of external mesh
node.bodyText:
Hi guys,
I am using a MOOSE-based application (SAM) for 3D fluid dynamics simulations. I have a relatively complex geometry and my mesh is built in ANSYS (scdoc) format. To get .exo format I do the following in ANSYS ICEM:

import model
merge all blocks
output mesh

by default, it is HEX8/QUAD4 mesh, which is suitable for FIRST polynomial order (LAGRANGE). This works fine.
I want to do simulations for SECOND order. If I specify so, I am getting the error:
Error: Exodus file says 20 nodes per Elem, but Elem type HEX8 has 8 nodes.
[0] ../src/mesh/exodusII_io.C, line 253, compiled Sep 20 2021 at 12:34:20
Then I tried to "Create node on interface" in ICEM and make the mesh HEX20/QUAD8. However, I am getting the same error in my simulation.
What is the problem? Thanks!

I dont know about a workflow to add the necessary nodes for second order. I suppose setting second_order = true in the [Mesh] block does not work?
@lindsayad do you know more about this?
Thank you for your answer. No, second_order = true does not work.

Using the same file you use for your HEX8 mesh and then specifying second_order = true in the mesh block should work. You say it doesn't work...do you get an error? Can you share your mesh block please?

No, I am not getting errors. The simulation just does not start. It is sort of frozen in the very beginning.
[Mesh]
type = FileMesh
file = hirjet_1st.exo
second_order = true
[]

Weird. it might just be working on the mesh.
Is your moose install recent? The current version should tell you what it s doing when it takes too long
yes, I installed MOOSE yesterday.
Is there any other way to save a moose-compatible mesh from .scdoc format?
How big is that mesh?

It is a 3D case:
--- Mesh Info ---
Element types :
HEXA_8 : 42756
QUAD_4 : 24016
Element parts :
ALL : 59952
INLET : 180
OUTLET : 180
WALL : 6460
Total elements : 66772
Total nodes : 47044
Min : -0.2027 -0.3548 -0.3048
Max : 0.5672 0.2413 0.3048

I dont know much about scdoc.
I wonder if having the Quads in the 3D mesh is the issue for loading it. Can you share that mesh with us?
I am sorry. Everything works fine. The problem was in the update of the cluster, so the output file was written in a different place. Sorry about that. BIG-BIG thanks for your help!

node.title: Unable to find the object of the individual modules
node.bodyText:
I recently installed moose and tried to run two examples :
(1.) https://github.com/idaholab/moose/tree/next/examples/ex01_inputfile
(2.) https://github.com/idaholab/moose/blob/next/modules/phase_field/examples/cahn-hilliard/Math_CH.i
While the first example runs perfectly, the app is unable to find the objects inside the phase field module in context of (2.) , and shows the following error:
*** ERROR ***
A 'CHMath' is not a registered object.

If you are trying to find this object in a dynamically linked library, make sure that
the library can be found either in your "Problem/library_path" parameter or in the
MOOSE_LIBRARY_PATH environment variable.

What might be the cause of this error?

What executable are you running?
If you're running the executable in /test (moose_test-opt), objects that are a part of the phase_field module are not compiled nor registered within this executable. If you want to run just phase_field examples, compile and use the phase_field executable:
cd /path/to/your/moose/repo
cd modules/phase_field
make -j 8
./phase_field-opt examples/cahn-hilliard/Math_CH.i

Thank you for the answers.
I was running the example traditionally with the external app.
I already compiled the phase field module to get the executable phase_field-opt, and I can run Math_CH.i example with phase_field-opt.
How do we then run the coupled simulations using more than two modules (e.g. phase_field and navier_stokes)? Is it possible through combined module ?
You can use the combined module OR you can change the Makefile in your application to include phase_field

I am asking this question because compiling the application (panther app) with the following option :
################################## MODULES ####################################
# To use certain physics included with MOOSE, set variables below to
# yes as needed.  Or set ALL_MODULES to yes to turn on everything (overrides
# other set variables).

ALL_MODULES                 := yes #no

#CHEMICAL_REACTIONS          := no
#CONTACT                     := no
#EXTERNAL_PETSC_SOLVER       := no
#FLUID_PROPERTIES            := no
#FSI                         := no
#FUNCTIONAL_EXPANSION_TOOLS  := no
#GEOCHEMISTRY                := no
#HEAT_CONDUCTION             := no
#LEVEL_SET                   := no
#MISC                        := no
#NAVIER_STOKES               := no
#PHASE_FIELD                 := yes #no
#POROUS_FLOW                 := no
#RAY_TRACING                 := no
#RDG                         := no
#RICHARDS                    := no
#STOCHASTIC_TOOLS            := no
#TENSOR_MECHANICS            := no
#XFEM                        := no


or separately including the PHASE_FIELD   := yes , showed the error mentioned in the first post.
did you try make clobberall then recompile
yes after every failed attempts, I had to redo with the $ make clobberall command

In fact, the app installed in another computer several years ago with moose environment works fine. I have not been able to use codes of individual modules with the external app only for the conda based moose installation.
can you post the result of ldd your_executable-opt please

the result of $ ldd panther-opt is as following:
linux-vdso.so.1 (0x00007ffd9f258000)
	libpanther_test-opt.so.0 => /home/username/moose_projects/panther/test/lib/libpanther_test-opt.so.0 (0x00007fe9abf70000)

ok the phase field module, or any module, is not compiled with your application.
This is very odd if you have the ALL_MODULES set to yes.
I would save all your work (commit) then git clean -xfd your repository then try again.
Another option  is to use dynamic loading. You just have to give in your input file the path to a compiled module library of phase_field.
See more info and the syntax here:
https://mooseframework.inl.gov/source/actions/DynamicObjectRegistrationAction.html

Thank you very much for your answer on dynamic object registration.  I could successfully run the input file consisting of objects from phase field module by using DynamicObjectRegistrationAction
[Problem]
  register_objects_from = 'PhaseFieldApp'
  library_path = '../../moose/modules/phase_field/lib'
[]

Are there any possibilities of loading objects dynamically from two or more modules?

node.title: Difference between PF formulations
node.bodyText:
Dear all,
I am investigating on  Phase Field formulations from Moose documentation and I do not understand something.
I have tried the same set-up (2 grains defined by 2 differents conserved variables but with the same material properties). In the first case I use the following kernels (TimeDerivative, CahnHilliard, CHInterface) and in the second one I defined a chemical potential for each grain and I use (CoupleTimeDerivative, SplitCHParsed, SplitCHWRes). Results are not the same and I do not understand this because formulations should be equivalent. I have maybe missunderstood something or made a coding error.
You wil find in the attachment the 2 input files.
PF_2grains_2Phases.txt
PF_2grains_2Phases_Test.txt
Thanks for all you can say.
I stay available. Regards.
Alexandre Sac--Morane

Moreover, I do not understand why variables c_i skyrocket like this with time! I have consider the same set-up and material as the example Conserved.i from the module combined. Is it because in my case the free energy depends on the 2 variables ?
@laagesen @SudiptaBiswas @amjokisaari on phase field.
Concerning this subject I found my error. The free energy was not well formulated.

Grains are usually represented by non-conserved order parameters. For simulating multiple grains, you should be looking at Allen-Cahn equation. Grain growth simulations would be a good place to start. If this doesn't help, please provide more information about the problem you are solving so you can point to right model to utilize.
Ok I will change my simulation. I let you know. Thanks
